title: Event Contours (Aspect)
goal: Learn event contour markers for beginning, ongoing, completion.

sections.content:
New Material (5-7 min)

What Are Event Contours?

Contours describe WHICH PART of an event you're talking about — beginning, middle, end.

Event Contour Markers

Cmavo Meaning Example
co'a beginning mi co'a sipna (I fall asleep)
ca'o ongoing mi ca'o gunka (I am working)
mo'u completion mi mo'u citka (I finished eating)
co'u cessation mi co'u tavla (I stop talking)

Examples

Beginning:

mi co'a sipna

I begin to sleep. (I fall asleep.)

Ongoing:

mi ca'o tcidu

I am reading. (In the middle of reading.)

Completion:

mi mo'u ciska

I finished writing.

Cessation:

mi co'u bajra

I stop running.

Contour vs Tense

  • Tense (pu/ca/ba): WHEN did it happen?
  • Contour (co'a/ca'o/mo'u): WHICH PART of the event?

Key Point

Contours describe event phases: co'a (start), ca'o (middle), mo'u (complete), co'u (stop).
sections.title: New Material (5-7 min)

sections.content:
Practice (4-5 min)

Exercise 1: Match Contour

Which contour fits?

  1. I begin eating. → ?
  2. I am eating. → ?
  3. I finished eating. → ?
  4. I stop eating. → ?
Answers
  1. mi co'a citka
  2. mi ca'o citka
  3. mi mo'u citka
  4. mi co'u citka

Exercise 2: Translate

Translate:

  1. I fall asleep. (begin sleeping)
  2. I am working.
  3. I finished the book.
Answers
  1. mi co'a sipna
  2. mi ca'o gunka
  3. mi mo'u tcidu lo cukta

Exercise 3: Describe Actions

Use contours to describe:

  1. Starting to run → ?
  2. In the middle of talking → ?
  3. Stopping work → ?
Answers
  1. mi co'a bajra
  2. mi ca'o tavla
  3. mi co'u gunka

Conversation Challenge (1-2 min)

Say aloud:

  1. "I'm working." → mi ca'o gunka
  2. "I finished eating." → mi mo'u citka
  3. "I stop." → mi co'u

Summary

You learned event contours: co'a (begin), ca'o (ongoing), mo'u (complete), co'u (cease). These describe phases of events.
